subject: Re: [junit] Performance of the  ant task
msgSnippet: Or you can just not use the junit task and launch one of the standard test runners that come with JUnit.  I prefer the output of the junit.textui.TestRunner,
messageBody:
Or you can just not use the junit task and launch one of the standard
test runners that come with JUnit. I prefer the output of the
junit.textui.TestRunner, anyway, and this way you can control which
tests run in which JVMs, etc. Here is our task:

<target name="junit.textui.alltests">
<echo>
========================================================================
==
RUNNING UNIT TESTS (with suffix ${suffix})
========================================================================
==
</echo>

<java classname="junit.textui.TestRunner" failonerror="yes"
fork="yes">
<classpath refid="test.classpath"/>
<arg value="com.digitalfocus.unittest.MasterTestSuite"/>
<sysproperty key="test.root.dir" path="${classes.dir}"/>
<sysproperty key="test.class.suffix" value="${suffix}"/>
</java>

<echo>
========================================================================
==
UNIT TESTS DONE
========================================================================
==
</echo>
</target>

> From: Stefan Bodewig [mailto:bodewig@...]

> Subject: Re: [junit] Performance of the <junit> ant task
>
>
> On Thu, 21 Feb 2002, <magnus@...> wrote:
>
> > So my question is, is this a correct understanding of the ant junit
> > task,
>
> Basically yes - but you should probably ask that on
> ant-user@.... 8-)
>
> > and are there any reasons why it should not run all tests in a
> > single process, to increase speed?
>
> fork="true" is not only there to get rid of Ant's classes, but also to
> isolate test cases from each other - tests that load native libraries
> and fail because a different test has already loaded them, tests that
> use Singletons and rely on a certain state and so on.
>
> Many things, the Singleton case above for example, can be solved by
> writing tests properly, but this was one additional reason to
> implement forking in <junit> as it is.
>
> Stefan
